article_text: Poly agricultural land are planted with Christmas trees, although DeLasaux said four others are available. “At the moment, the thought is that we don’t want to plant more trees because we don’t want to appear too commercial and compete with local growers,” he said. “First and foremost, the project is supposed to be an educational experience.” Curtis Edson, the tree farm manager and a natural resources senior, said, “A lot more is involved than people think. It doesn’t just entail selling the trees. It takes a lot of time and effort to maintain (the trees).” DeLasaux said the students involved learn everything there is to know about growing the trees, particularly overall maintenance and how to manage this type of project. In February, Edson said the stumps left from the cut trees wtII be removed, the land tilled and seedlings planted to continue the growing cycle.
